Award.AwardTitle: Indiana Noyce Science Scholars: Teachers for a New Decade

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Indiana Noyce Science Scholars: Teachers for a New Decade project partners faculty in the College of Arts and Sciences and the School of Education at Indiana University-Bloomington (IUB) with Bartholomew Consolidated School Corporation, North Lawrence Community Schools, Monroe County Community School Corporation, North Daviess Community Schools and Paoli Community Schools in support of developing sixty individuals to become middle grades and high school science teachers over the course of five years. The project provides for two pathways to produce the STEM teachers: 1) a discipline-specific B.S./M.S. program in biology, chemistry, physics, and geology, in which qualified science majors earn both a baccalaureate degree in a STEM discipline and a master's degree in education, as well as science teacher licensure and 2) the Transition to Teaching (T2T) program, which is a vehicle for graduate science majors and career changes who hold degrees in science and engineering fields to meet the requirements for science teacher licensure in Indiana.

The conceptual framework for this Teachers for a New Decade project is summarized by "Six Principles for Teacher Education," which have been developed over multiple years by IUB faculty and speak to Knowledge, Meaningful Experience, Personalized Learning, Community, Critical Reflection, and Growth. This program is NCATE approved. The project includes a Noyce Mentor Coordinator who serves as a resource to Noyce Scholar-Teachers during their first year. This individual complements the teacher mentors in the schools by connecting them with relevant IUB faculty, thus ensuring responsiveness to content-driven needs of the fledgling Noyce Teachers. In addition to face-to-face mentoring, the project will utilize the "PBS TeacherLine Peer Connection" online induction delivery platform, which embeds research briefs along with short video podcasts modeling research-based best practice instructional strategies, along with Twitter or other real-time social media applications that are adaptable to coaching.

The formative aspect of the evaluation will examine: the extent to which faculty and administrators make use of results and materials from prior NSF projects and the research literature on minority recruitment and supports; the effectiveness of "cohort" and mentoring in scholar/teachers' retention and completion; and institutional capacity building and changes needed to recruit and support cross-disciplinary students entering STEM education. The summative evaluation will focus on: how the scholar/teachers' content knowledge and prior experiences influence their instructional decision-making; which components of the preparation program have the greatest impact on induction experiences; how the supervision and mentoring components facilitated the transition from pre-service into teaching; and how these aspects of the project influenced teacher retention of the scholar/teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report for NSF Award Number 1035234


The Indiana Noyce Science Scholars: Teachers for a New Decade project was an effort by both the School of Education and College of Arts and Sciences faculty to increase the number of high quality science teachers from Indiana University Bloomington (IUB).


Three major instructional vehicles were used in the program. The Secondary Transition to Teaching (ST2T) program is an intensive 11 month program by which students with strong academic backgrounds in an area complete coursework, extended practicums and student teaching (http://education.indiana.edu/graduate/programs/secondary-t2t/). A second program was the Community of Teachers (COT) program, a more individualized program that provides students a longer term of experience working with one mentor teacher (http://education.indiana.edu/undergraduate/programs/secondary/secondary-cot.html). The third program was a new, a Joint B.S./M.S. Ed program, where students in the College of Arts and Sciences can take both College of Arts and Sciences courses and School of Education courses during their last undergraduate semester. This allows the students to complete their B.S. degree, teacher licensure and an M.S. Ed., in Secondary Education all within a five year period. (http://education.indiana.edu/undergraduate/programs/secondary/joint-degree.html)


Several methods were used to recruit Noyce Scholars. Meetings and information flyers were provided to each of the five relevant departments along with meetings with undergraduate advisers. The faculty committee that reviewed Noyce candidates also assisted with identifying and encouraging students to apply. Letters were sent to every four year college in the state, an ad was run in the student newspaper and a on the NRP stations in both Bloomington and Indianapolis. A website was maintained along with interviews with prospective applicants by the PI and Co-PI.


While these recruitment methods met with some success they did not produce the 44 scholars that were the goal of the program. Forty-one students started one of the three programs with 34 completing the program, four are currently in the program as of this date, and three did not complete the program.


In reflecting on the inability for the program to attract the expected number, the program staff identified four probable reasons. One, the national decrease in students enrolling in Teacher Preparation program (down 38.8% 2010-2015) and specifically in Indiana programs (down 51.3%) in the same time period (Title II data, https://title2.ed.gov/Public/Home.aspx ).


Secondly, Indiana University, while highly regarded, is not in a major metropolitan area and all the programs in place to prepare teachers require on campus attendance and field experiences in local schools. While the programs were relatively short, students did have to move to the Bloomington area to participate.


Third, as with every major university, faculty tend not to cross college/school lines when working on projects. While our advisory committee was most helpful, it was difficult to attract faculty that would be proactive in recommending students.

Finally, as in practically any project, project management could have been better. The original PI took on the additional position of Associate Dean for Research for the School of Education which took time from grant responsibilities.


Our external evaluator has reported that the Noyce scholars that she has observed and interviewed are very strong first year teachers. While missing the numbers mark, the project is confident it helped to develop excellent science teachers.


Key outcomes of the program were the strengthening of our programs and pipelines for training much-needed teachers in science disciplines and strengthening of ties between the School of Education and faculty in the science disciplines served by the Noyce program at Indiana University.
